keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed to meet operational specifications and was not certified for passenger use, contributing to a deadly crash in September 2025.

The cable snapped shortly after the funicular cars began moving along Calçada da Glória, causing one car to derail and crash into a building, resulting in at least 16 fatalities and multiple injuries.
Eyewitnesses described the incident as chaotic and uncontrolled, with one man named Bruno recounting the sound of screams, a loud bang, and a cloud of brown smoke.

An interim investigation by the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
Maintenance records show that tasks were marked as completed even when not actually performed, and the maintenance plan was falsely recorded as 'compliant and accepted' by the operator CARRIS.
The preliminary findings are not conclusive, and a final report is expected to be released next year.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fatal cable failure on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, killed at least 16 people and injured several others. A preliminary investigation by the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) found that the steel cable did not meet certification or operational specifications set by the operator CARRIS, and that maintenance records were falsified, with tasks falsely marked as completed. Eyewitnesses described the crash as chaotic and uncontrolled, with one man named Bruno reporting the sound of screams and a loud bang. The interim findings are not conclusive, and a final report is expected to be released next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
